body.p:
Louisville Ky -- June 13th 1865
T, E, Bramlett Gov, Ky --

Your petitioners would most respectfully aask that you extend to Ben Duke a free man of Col, of this place Execative Clemency & remit his bail Bond ^as surety^ in the case of the Commonwealth vs Henry King, Ben is his surety on his bond for $300 We have known Ben Duke for many years and take pleasure in testifying to you that he is a man of good moral character & an exception among free men of his colour, & have never known him in trouble at law before. & we farther state that we are satisfied that the community will approve of your action, Ben is worthey he is quite old and infirm -- & has a large family to suport

James P Chambers
E, M, Stone
B. R Pollard
J. E. Pilcher
Saml Matlock
Jos Clement
I understand that Ben Duke is a colored (free) man & has a good name & is now in bad health & have heard several good & prominent citizens speak in high terms of him
I know Ben Duke he is a most Excellenc clever man & I concur in all that Mr. Dupuy has said
Duke has at no time since my acquaintance of several years with him, had business in court but has always been a quiet Law abiding citizen
This is the only Penalty I ever asked your Excellency to Remit and ask you to remit this for the great regard I have for the good reputation of Ben
W. A Ronald S J C
I know the Petitioner and believe he is entitled to & pray to him
Floyd between market & main East side opis judgings at shed

Jefferson Cir Ct
vs
Ben Duke f. m. c.
$300,
Forfieture
Remitted
6 Sept 1865
Floyd between market & Main East side issue Judging
